title: Chinese capital of pet toys faces harsh impact of the trade war
summary: Twenty years ago, Shuitou, a factory town in Zhejiang, had to close its 1,000 leather tanneries due to excessive pollution. Gradually repurposed into a global hub for pet accessories, it now faces a new threat from US tariffs.

title: Netanyahu instructs negotiators to continue steps to release Gaza hostages
summary: Meanwhile, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu made a rare visit to Gaza on Tuesday as the military pressed on with its air and ground assault against the Palestinian territory.

title: Zelensky says Ukraine and US are nearing a deal on strategic minerals
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky says talks with Washington on a long-delayed minerals agreement are making 'good progress,' with a deal potentially days away.

title: Arsenal knock out Real Madrid to reach Champions League semi-finals
summary: Arsenal beat Real Madrid 2-1 on Wednesday, with winger Gabriel Martinelli scoring a late winner for the English team. Madrid's increasingly slim hopes were dashed when Mbappé limped off field with an ankle injury with 15 minutes remaining after a clash with Declan Rice.

title: 'Russia has no regard for climate issues'
summary: Under Vladimir Putin's regime, harmful subterranean exploitation projects have multiplied, and Russian greenhouse gas emissions have significantly increased, say historians Laurent Coumel and Marc Elie.

title: Art market: Collectible posters remain affordable
summary: Witnesses to the industrial revolution at the turn of the 19th and 20th centuries, advertising posters, celebrated in an exhibition at the Musée d'Orsay, remain accessible at reasonable prices.

title: Zuckerberg denies Meta bought rivals to conquer them
summary: The co-founder of Facebook, in court on Wednesday, responded 'No' when asked by Meta attorney Mark Hansen if his intent was to eliminate rivals with the purchases of photo-sharing app Instagram and messaging service WhatsApp.

title: California to sue US government over 'self-destructive' Trump tariffs
summary: The case is the latest of more than a dozen lawsuits that California has filed against the Trump administration. Governor Gavin Newsom, until recently, has spent much of the last three months trying to avoid open conflict with Trump due to the need for federal assistance after the fires swept through Los Angeles in January.

title: Island-wide blackout paralyzes Puerto Rico ahead of Easter weekend
summary: Puerto Rico plunged into darkness Wednesday as a sweeping blackout left all 1.4 million customers without power, disrupting Easter travel, shuttering businesses, and reigniting outrage over the island’s fragile energy grid.

title: Sweden falls in love with a novel about growing old
summary: 'When the Cranes Fly South,' the debut novel by a sociology doctoral student, has captivated nearly 200,000 readers in a country of ten million inhabitants, where reading is on the decline. This bestseller is set to be translated into about 30 languages and will be released in France in 2026.

title: In Nepal, widespread discontent fuels calls for the restoration of the monarchy
summary: While the former authoritarian monarch remains controversial, the movement in his favor reflects the frustration of some Nepalis given the instability that has prevailed since the country became a republic in 2008.

title: French prison attacks: Investigators explore all leads, from drug traffickers to the far left
summary: For three nights in a row, coordinated attacks have set vehicles on fire in prison parking lots across the country. One prison even faced heavy weapons fire.

title: Why is it so difficult for France and Algeria to stabilize their relationship?
summary: After a brief respite, the rift between Paris and Algiers was once again reignited by the expulsion of 12 French embassy agents in retaliation for the detention of an employee of the Algerian consulate in Paris.

title: The first time Le Monde wrote 'tiger mosquito'
summary: On La Réunion, the chikungunya epidemic has peaked with more than 33,000 cases and six deaths recorded. Like dengue or Zika, the virus is transmitted by the tiger mosquito. On July 30, 1948, the insect was mentioned for the first time in Le Monde, which has since continued to track its spread.

title: Macron vows French prison attackers will be 'found, tried and punished'
summary: Since Sunday, unknown assailants have targeted several jails and facilities across France, torching cars, spraying the entrance of one prison with automatic fire and leaving mysterious inscriptions.

title: UK Supreme Court rules definition of 'woman' based on sex at birth
summary: Five judges in Britain's top court unanimously ruled on Wednesday that 'the terms 'woman' and 'sex' in the Equality Act 2010 refer to a biological woman, and biological sex.'

title: 'Russian gas and Europe is an old story that ended badly, but Trump seems ready to revive it'
summary: Nord Stream, season 2? The idea of reactivating the pipeline via a US company, as part of ceasefire negotiations in Ukraine, has awoken the German appetite for cheap Russian gas. This project would be devastating for European unity, notes Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann.

title: What do Russians dream of? Le Monde's photo report on nine ordinary citizens in the shadow of war
summary: After more than three years of war with Ukraine, the voices of Russians, silenced by the Kremlin, remain rare. How do they envision their future and that of their country at a time of new geopolitical shifts? Photographer Mary Gelman collected nine testimonies.

title: Rights groups accuse US of using El Salvador's mega-prison as secretive deportation dump
summary: Rights groups are raising alarms over the Trump administration's mass deportation of migrants to El Salvador's notorious CECOT prison, where hundreds are being held incommunicado without charges and prompting comparisons to a 'Guantanamo on steroids'.

title: US Secretary of State Rubio heads to Paris to meet Macron for talks on Ukraine
summary: The meeting comes as the Trump administration grapples with stalled efforts to secure a ceasefire in Ukraine and rising tensions in the Middle East and Iran.

title: China is introducing new restrictions on Hollywood films
summary: A regulatory wall curbs the presence of American cinema, subjected to import quotas, reduced revenue, and bans on screenings during holiday periods. American films account for only 5% of the box office in China.

title: Amman hospital heals the bodies and souls of children who escaped the hell of Gaza
summary: The World Health Organization estimates that between 11,000 and 13,000 Palestinians – including 4,500 children – need emergency medical evacuation from the enclave. Israeli authorities are preventing exits through Rafah, the crossing point to Egypt.

title: The spiritual messages hidden inside the works of JRR Tolkien
summary: Is 'The Lord of the Rings' a Catholic epic? Some consider it a parable of the Gospels, much to the dismay of several scholars who believe Tolkien subtly incorporated various mythologies. On the occasion of a Paris exhibit featuring tapestries inspired by his texts, we delve into the mysteries of this world-encompassing work.

title: US judge finds 'probable cause' to hold Trump officials in contempt over deportation order
summary: District Judge James Boasberg on Wednesday cited evidence that the government had engaged in 'deliberate or reckless disregard' of his order to halt flights of more than 200 alleged Venezuelan gang members to El Salvador.

title: Ceasefire in Ukraine: Why Western allies' talks are stalling
summary: Disagreements over sending troops to Ukraine are just the tip of the iceberg in much tougher negotiations over the country's 'militarization,' according to numerous European sources who are increasingly speaking out openly.

title: Hermès to hike US prices to offset 10% tariff impact
summary: The French luxury group announced on Thursday the price increases would take effect on May 1 and would 'fully offset' the tariff impact.

title: The Turkish protests, a work of art
summary: Protesters mobilized since the arrest of Istanbul's mayor, Ekrem Imamoglu, are showcasing immense creativity, humor and subversion to express their anger at President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

title: Gaza photojournalist Fatima Hassouna killed in a strike with 10 of her relatives
summary: The young woman is at the center of a documentary film by director Sepideh Farsi, selected for the 2025 Cannes Film Festival.

title: Book claims Vatican already knew of sexual abuse accusations in 1950s against French charity icon
summary: In a book published on Thursday, two journalists reveal that they consulted archives showing that the Holy See was aware of Abbé Pierre's actions 'as early as autumn 1955.'

title: US farmers are gravely concerned by the impact of Trump's trade war
summary: Farmers across the country continue to largely support the US president. However, they hope to avoid the fallout of the Trump administration's tariffs dispute and secure assistance from the federal government.

title: Haiti still plagued by 'independence debt' after 200 years: 'We continue to pay the ransom through underdevelopment'
summary: Haitian essayist and speaker Monique Clesca urges Emmanuel Macron to acknowledge the 'injustice' committed two centuries ago when the nation achieved independence and France imposed a heavy debt burden on the young republic.

title: Zelensky's top aide and foreign minister to meet US and EU officials in Paris
summary: The parties will discuss a potential full ceasefire, the involvement of international peacekeepers and the development of Ukraine's security framework, according to a statement from Ukraine's Foreign Ministry.

title: The decoupling of China and the US amid the trade war
summary: The escalation of tariffs initiated by Donald Trump is setting the stage for a dramatic shift in the global economy with the irreversible distancing of the world's two leading industrial, technological and financial powers.

title: Trump slams Fed chairman Jerome Powell over interest rates
summary: US President Donald Trump railed against the US Federal Reserve's high interest rates, while Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said Trump's tariffs could force him to choose between fighting inflation or unemployment.

title: French government faces calls for slavery reparations
summary: The Foundation for the Memory of Slavery has called on France to address the sensitive issue of reparations for its colonial past, coinciding with the bicentennial of Haiti's debt on April 17.

title: Romania takes steps to prevent social media manipulation during presidential election
summary: The organizers of the May election want to prevent a repeat of November 2024, when the vote was canceled following revelations of a large-scale TikTok manipulation operation.

title: French prison attacks: Perpetrators' motivations still unclear
summary: The actions targeting French penitentiary centers or their staff over the past nights, including vehicle fires, drone flyovers and shootings, reveal varying methods of operation.

title: Macron announces joint commission to examine Haiti's independence debt to France
summary: The French president did not, however, address longstanding Haitian demands for reparations over what is referred to as a 'double debt,' 200 years after the Caribbean nation's independence.

title: Within NATO, unease is spreading between the American military and European allies
summary: Europeans are waiting to be informed about the Trump administration's specific plans regarding its potential withdrawal of troops from their continent. They are closely watching the appointments and dismissals at the Pentagon.

title: Northern Irish designer Jonathan Anderson takes helm at Dior Men
summary: Anderson, who for a decade turned around the fortunes of the heritage Spanish brand Loewe, is an influential tastemaker with many A-list fans.
